content.description: Brief Psychotic Disorder is characterized by the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms such as delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, or grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior, lasting at least one day but less than one month, with eventual full return to premorbid level of functioning.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Presence of one (or more) of the following symptoms: (1) delusions, (2) hallucinations, (3) disorganized speech, (4) grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior. At least one must be (1), (2), or (3). B. Duration of an episode is at least 1 day but less than 1 month, with eventual full return to premorbid level of functioning. C. The disturbance is not better explained by major depressive or bipolar disorder with psychotic features, or another psychotic disorder, and is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.
content.prevalence: Rare, estimated 0.1% in general population; higher rates in developing countries and postpartum period.
content.age_of_onset: Typically late adolescence to early adulthood; may occur postpartum.
content.prognosis: Generally good with complete remission in most cases, but recurrence possible; risk of progression to schizophrenia spectrum disorders in some individuals.

circuitry: Acute dysregulation of dopaminergic pathways, particularly in mesolimbic system.
neurochemistry: Increased dopamine activity in psychotic episodes.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: Possible genetic vulnerability; often precipitated by extreme stress or trauma.

history_psychosocial: Onset timing, precipitating stressors, symptom course, prior psychiatric history, and family psychiatric history.
medical_assessment: Rule out delirium, seizure disorder, intoxication, or withdrawal.
Basic labs: CBC, CMP, TSH, urine toxicology; consider brain imaging if neurological symptoms.
standardized_measures: Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) or Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS).
risk_stratification: Assess for suicidal or homicidal risk during psychosis.
evaluation.team_and_process: Multidisciplinary approach with psychiatry, social work, and family support.

cognitive: Brief disruption in attention and thought organization

severity_levels.mild: Minimal disruption; rapid symptom resolution within days.
severity_levels.moderate: Marked disruption in functioning for 1â€“3 weeks.
severity_levels.severe: Severe symptoms requiring hospitalization; lasting up to one month.

psychological: History of trauma or extreme stress sensitivity

impact_on_life.school_work: Acute inability to perform occupational or academic duties.
impact_on_life.medical: Risk of injury or neglect during psychosis.
impact_on_life.emotional: High distress during and after episode.

medications: Short-term antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone, olanzapine, haloperidol) for acute symptoms
care_coordination: Close follow-up after discharge to monitor recurrence or progression

treatment_goals: Prevent harm to self or others
missed_diagnosis_factors: Misattributing symptoms to substance intoxication without confirming course
overdiagnosis_factors: Labeling acute stress reactions as psychosis without core psychotic symptoms

specifiers.with_marked_stressors: Brief reactive psychosis following an identifiable stressor
specifiers.with_postpartum_onset: Onset during pregnancy or within 4 weeks postpartum

warning_signs: Sudden onset of hallucinations or delusions
self_help_strategies: Engage in treatment immediately after symptom onset

adolescence: May present with abrupt behavioral changes and paranoia
older_adults: Less common; rule out delirium or medical causes

real_life_examples: A 28-year-old woman develops hallucinations and disorganized speech three days after a traumatic breakup; symptoms resolve fully within two weeks of antipsychotic treatment.
content.when_to_seek_help: Immediate psychiatric evaluation for sudden onset of hallucinations, delusions, or disorganized behavior.
